Riegel Power Model

Source: R/models.R
Riegel_power.Rd

Calculates running power based on distance using Riegel's model and di Prampero's equation.

Riegel_power(
  Distance,
  a,
  b,
  C1 = 3.86,
  C2 = 0.4,
  C3 = 2,
  BMR = 1.2,
  BSA = 1.8,
  BM = 70,
  eff = 0.2
)

Arguments

Distance

Numeric. Running distance in meters (must be positive).

a

Numeric. Empirical constant dependent on measurement units (must be positive).

b

Numeric. "Fatigue factor" constant as described by Riegel (must be positive).

C1

Numeric. Parameter of the equation. Default is 3.86.

C2

Numeric. Parameter of the equation. Default is 0.4.

C3

Numeric. Parameter of the equation. Default is 2.

BMR

Numeric. Basal metabolic rate in W/kg. Default is 1.2.

BSA

Numeric. Body surface area in m^2. Default is 1.8.

BM

Numeric. Body mass in kg. Default is 70.

eff

Numeric. Assumed mechanical efficiency. Default is 0.2.

Value

Numeric. Power output in watts.

References

Riegel, Peter S. "Athletic Records and Human Endurance: A Time-vs.-Distance Equation Describing World-Record Performances May Be Used to Compare the Relative Endurance Capabilities of Various Groups of People." American Scientist 69, no. 3 (1981): 285–90. http://www.jstor.org/stable/27850427.

Examples

Riegel_power(Distance = 1000, a = 2.5, b = 1.06)
#> [1] 31.08472
